In today’s top news, Visa reported mixed Q2 earnings, and Starbucks reported a drop in rewards members in its Q3 earnings. Plus, Mastercard offers concessions over Nets deal to win antitrust approval. Visa Sees Gains In Online and Contactless Transactions ... In today’s top news, Visa reported mixed Q2 earnings, and Starbucks reported a drop...

In today’s top news, Visa reported mixed Q2 earnings, and Starbucks reported a drop in rewards members in its Q3 earnings. Plus, Mastercard offers concessions over Nets deal to win antitrust approval. Visa Sees Gains In Online and Contactless Transactions ...

In today’s top news, Visa reported mixed Q2 earnings, and Starbucks reported a drop in rewards members in its Q3 earnings. Plus, Mastercard offers concessions over Nets deal to win antitrust approval. Visa Sees Gains In Online and Contactless Transactions In Q2 Visa reported Tuesday (July 28) that its second-quarter results suffered from plummeting consumer spending amid COVID-19, although the pandemic did boost online spending and contactless cards. Starbucks Rewards Members Drop To 16.3M Amid Pandemic Starbucks reported in its third quarter earnings results on Tuesday (July 28) that the ranks of its 90-day active Starbucks Rewards members dropped 5 percent year over year in the U.S. to 16.3 million because of “reduced customer frequency.” Mastercard Says It Will Bend To Win EU Approval For Nets Deal Mastercard Inc. is offering concessions in an effort to defuse the European Union’s antitrust concerns about its planned acquisition of Nets Group, the Scandinavian payment firm. Senators Want New PPP Program With Different Guidelines It’s looking increasingly likely that Congress will vote on a new round of COVID-19 stimulus funding, with the Paycheck Protection Program (PPP) an increasing area of focus. The latest plan put forward by Senate Republicans calls for a fresh round of funding for PPP loans, although this time with somewhat narrowed eligibility criteria. Mastercard’s Head Of Innovation: How The Microsoft Partnership Will Boost Digital Commerce Globally Mastercard and Microsoft share many goals when it comes to building a bigger future for digital commerce and making it more accessible to consumers worldwide. Ken Moore, head of Mastercard Labs, tells Karen Webster a recently announced collaboration between the two is a natural way to combine their respective strengths and create solutions on a truly global scale. What To Expect From Big Tech’s Fab Four Capitol Hill Grill Today marks a red letter day for Big Tech. The heads of Google, Amazon, Apple and Facebook will appear (virtually) before a House subcommittee that’s examining online platforms. Lawmakers and regulators have been scrutinizing these marquee names’ business efforts, training laser sights on what they deem to be anti-competitive practices. But is all the finger-pointing misplaced? The Coming World Of Going To The Movies … In Your Living Room AMC Entertainment Holdings has reached agreement with Universal Studios allowing films go to premium video-streaming services after just 17 days in cinemas. —————————— New PYMNTS Study: Subscription Commerce Conversion Index – July 2020 Staying home 24/7 has consumers turning to subscription services for both entertainment and their day-to-day needs. While that’s a great opportunity for providers, it also presents a challenge — 27.4 million consumers are looking to cancel their subscriptions because of friction and cost concerns. In the latest Subscription Commerce Conversion Index , PYMNTS reveals the five key features that can help companies keep subscribers loyal despite today’s challenging economic times. Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5T3X-N731-JCMN-Y2JH-00000-00Today In Useless Surveys: Some People Want Internet Companies To Stop Filtering News And Some Don't.2018-08-24T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:37:29ZLexisNexisToday In Useless Surveys: Some People Want Internet Companies To Stop Filtering News And Some Don't.Mike Masnick

Aug 24, 2018( Techdirt: http://www.techdirt.com Delivered by Newstex) Sometimes public sentiment is useful. And sometimes it's only useful in demonstrating how little the general public understands some issues. It would appear that a new survey done by the Knight Foundation[1] about how the internet giants should handle "news" content is one of the latter ones. While there's lots of discussion about what the poll results "say," the only thing they really say is that the public has no clue about how the internet and news works -- and that should be the focus.

We need much greater tech and media literacy. Unfortunately, the poll seems more likely to do the opposite. There are two "headline" findings out of the report -- and the fact that the two are almost entirely contradictory should have maybe been a warning sign: Internet platforms shouldn't make any effort to "customize" the newsfeed that you see and show the same thing to everyone Internet platforms should be "subject to the same regulations and newspapers and TV stations."Let's dig in a bit to the full survey. The first point is actually split into two separate parts, and the results aren't unsurprising, but (again) really seem to demonstrate media and tech illiteracy more than anything else. First, they were asked if they think it was a good or bad idea for platforms to target news based on interests, and the breakdown here really isn't that definitive in either direction. It's pretty split: https://imgur.com/xbklntmThis seems perfectly reasonable because the question is kind of... dumb? I mean, it really depends on what kind of service I'm using. If I'm using Twitter, which is a feed-based system where the entire point is to have an ongoing stream of everything the people/organizations I follow tweet, then, I'd be against targeting news, because that's not what I use Twitter for. If it were something else, like Google News, where the entire point is to recommend news, then I'm a lot more open to it. So, the whole premise of this question seems silly. Really, the issue here is that people should know what kind of site they're looking at, and whether it's recommending news or giving you a firehose of news. That's all. But this question doesn't get at that, and I'm guessing that's why the responses are so mixed. But then there's a question about whether platforms should "exclude" certain kinds of content. And we get the following responses:   https://imgur.com/u4ye7oaAnd there's a related question about how concerned people are about platforms excluding news:   https://imgur.com/UasUKN0Again, while these results can make headlines, they all seem kind of useless. Most people feel that platforms should exclude content that is "misinformation." Well, duh. But that doesn't tell us anything all that interesting, really. And then the latter results seem to conflict with that view, because it claims that the vast majority of people are concerned that platforms excluding news would give people a biased view and restrict expression and such. But... they want to exclude misinformation. Basically, it all goes back to one of the key problems that we've had with the big debate on content moderation. Tons of people are for moderation of "bad" content, but they worry (correctly) that moderation done badly will do bad things. And they don't trust the moderators from big tech companies. What does that really tell us? Not very much. Because all of these are conflating a bunch of different sites and different issues, such that anyone can basically cherry pick what they want out of it to try to support their own position. Want to use this study to show that internet platforms should moderate content to get rid of "fake news" (without ever defining fake news)? Show the results that people want platforms to intervene there. Want to use this study to show that people don't trust internet platforms to moderate at all? Show the other results. What useful points can be gleaned from this? So far, mainly just that this study is useless. So, you see stories about this study claiming that Americans think platforms should stop filtering news[2], even though only some of the study says that, and other parts say the exact opposite. And then there's another hidden tidbit that was the lead in some of the press coverage: that "Americans favor more regulation of internet sites."[3] Regulation of what and how? Well, again, this study fails completely in that it never actually says. The only bit on regulation is the following:Seventy-nine percent of Americans strongly or somewhat agree that major internet companies should be subject to the same rules and regulations as newspapers and broadcast news stations are. Twenty percent strongly or somewhat disagree.That's it. Literally, that's it. There's a little bit more of a discussion about the breakdown based on age, but there is no discussion of what the fuck this even means -- because it means literally nothing. What "regulations" do newspapers and broadcast news face? Well, not much? But, it really kind of depends. Broadcast news may face some FCC regulations because they use the public airwaves. But newspapers don't. And internet sites don't. Because they don't use the public airwaves. Other than that, they already face the same basic "rules and regulations." So it's not at all clear how -- as a bunch of people have claimed -- this study supports the idea for "increased" regulation of internet sites. Honestly, this feels like a kind of push poll and it's kind of shameful that the Knight Foundation and Gallup -- both of which should know better -- would do such a thing. After asking all these random amorphous meaningless questions about internet platforms, they then jump in with a question about regulating the platforms without defining or clarifying what regulations they're even talking about, in an area where the vast majority of the public will have literally no idea what those limited regulations are? What good is that other than to just get people to say "sure, they should all be on an equal footing." About the only interesting tidbit I can find in the entire damn study is that those who are moderately technically savvy -- defined as "very familiar with computer algorithms" -- are marginally more inclined than those who are less tech savvy to say that end users should be responsible for finding accurate and unbiased news, rather than the internet platforms. But that's really about it.   https://imgur.com/QdlC3mqSo, what are we left with? A weird survey that feels more like a push poll, that lets anyone take the info and make any argument they want. When the only conclusions that seem to really come out if it are: (1) this is a really awful and confusing survey, and (2) most people have no idea what regulations there are around news.Permalink[4] | Comments[5] | Email This Story[6] [ 1]:   https://www.knightfoundation.org/reports/major-internet-companies-as-news-editors [ 2]:   https://www.cjr.org/the_media_today/americans-platforms-news-filtering.php [ 3]:   http://www.baltimoresun.com/entertainment/tv/z-on-tv-blog/bs-fe-zontv-gallup-internet-poll-20180814-story.html [ 4]:   https://www.techdirt.com/articles/20180816/17555640447/today-useless-surveys-some-people-want-internet-companies-to-stop-filtering-news-some-dont.shtml [ 5]:   https://www.techdirt.com/articles/20180816/17555640447/today-useless-surveys-some-people-want-internet-companies-to-stop-filtering-news-some-dont.shtml#comments [ 6]:   https://www.techdirt.com/articles/20180816/17555640447/today-useless-surveys-some-people-want-internet-companies-to-stop-filtering-news-some-dont.shtml?op=sharethis

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:60G4-BK91-JCMN-Y323-00000-00Today's Congressional Hearing Will Test Big Tech's Simplest Algorithm: If An Ex-Regulator, Then Hire2020-07-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:37:29ZLexisNexisToday's Congressional Hearing Will Test Big Tech's Simplest Algorithm: If An Ex-Regulator, Then HireNicole Lafond

Jul 29, 2020( Talking Points Memo: http://talkingpointsmemo.com/ Delivered by Newstex) This article is part ofTPM Cafe[1], TPM's home for opinion and news analysis. After months of heightened antitrust scrutiny, the House Judiciary Committee has finally set up a blockbuster confrontation with big tech: the CEOs of Apple, Amazon, Google and Facebook will testify Wednesday before the committee on their companies' dominance as digital platforms.The hearing is part of the Antitrust Subcomittee's investigation into the companies and the 'adequacy of existing antitrust laws and enforcement[2].' While the congressional hearing itself won't break up big tech, the actual antitrust enforcers are also investigating those same companies: the Department of Justice Antitrust Division is pushing forward[3] with their investigation into Google, while the Federal Trade Commission continues its probe[4] into Google, Amazon, Apple, Facebook and Microsoft. As American Economic Liberties Project's Sarah Miller recently explained[5], this cross-political party effort to confront monopoly power was unthinkable 18 months ago, yet takes on even more importance as the pandemic further entrenches the power of the four companies which dominate e-commerce, social media, online advertising and the Apple App Store respectively. Yet these companies knew for years that a reckoning was in the works.

They've been building up their defenses, and a key component of that defense is the antitrust enforcement officials who take a trip through the revolving door to the benefit of corporate clients. At antitrust enforcement agencies like the FTC — where 52 of 81 officials[6] joined private law firms or acquisition-fueled corporations after departing the Commission — defending corporate clients after ostensibly serving public interests is increasingly the norm. This norm extends to the legislative branch as well as the executive: Hal Singer recently wrote[7] in the American Prospect on the concerning rise of congressional staffers flocking to big tech jobs, taking with them knowledge of the latest attempts to fix holes in antitrust laws and regulation. Singer expertly dissects the conflicts of interest in these professional moves, noting 'there's a strong public-interest motive to deny this free exercise of movement from government to the corporate sector if it conflicts with proper corporate regulation.' The tech giants facing the hot seat in July benefit from and feed into this culture both through direct hires, retaining BigLaw counsel that also hires former antitrust officials[8], and through the general corruption of incentives at the enforcement agencies which favors corporate interests over public. Amazon has directly hired at least four antitrust officials since the beginning of the year. The Revolving Door Project previously tracked[9] at least three FTC officials who joined Amazon in early 2020: Amy Posner and Elisa Kantor Perlman became corporate counsels, and Antara Dutta became a principal economist. Amazon's newest hire, Scott Fitzgerald, hails from the DOJ Antitrust Division, where he worked on health care industry cases in the Litigation I Section and eventually became the assistant chief of the Healthcare and Consumer Products Section. Fitzgerald joined Amazon in May as an in-house antitrust corporate counsel. With Bezos's upcoming testimony and Amazon's ongoing DOJ investigation[10], Fitzgerald will soon find himself in the position of defending Amazon against the members of Congress who just three months ago oversaw his work, as well as his colleagues at the DOJ. He joins fellow revolver Nate Sutton, the Amazon competition counsel and former DOJ Antitrust lawyer who is under investigation[11] for potentially misleading Congress on the company's data practices. Sutton testified that Amazon doesn't use 'individual seller data directly to compete' with third-party businesses, a claim the Wall Street Journal proved false earlier this year[12]. There's also Bryson Bachman, the former senior counsel to Assistant Attorney General Makan Delrahim. Amazon poached[13] Bachman amidst heightened antitrust scrutiny in 2018. And we would be remiss not to mention that antitrust expert and former DOJ Antitrust official Fiona Scott Morton has been advising[14] both Amazon and Apple. Morton has co-authored papers on the antitrust case against Google[15] and Facebook[16], and has espoused guidance on the future of antitrust enforcement, all the while getting paid by the other half of the big tech problem. Morton likely advises Amazon and Apple through her position as a senior consultant[17] with Charles River Associates, one of the economic consulting firms[18] that sell expert insight to both the antitrust agencies and corporations. In fact, Amazon needn't always hire former antitrust officials directly. Bezos is being advised by Covington & Burling[19], a politically-connected BigLaw firm that boasts[20] at least 13 competition lawyers that worked for either the FTC or DOJ Antitrust before joining the firm, including former FTC commissioner (and former Biden advisor) Terrell McSweeny. Amazon's named counsel from Covington is Robert K. Kelner, who specializes[21] in guiding corporations through congressional investigations. Amazon is not alone in its aggressive poaching: the rest of big tech has also hired former antitrust officials to bolster their legal teams. Back in 2018, Facebook made headlines[22] for hiring the former DOJ Antitrust chief in San Francisco, Kate Patchen, amidst increasing[23] antitrust scrutiny. Facebook is pulling a similar move this year: the company hired former FTC deputy director Barbara Blank[24] this April. Blank led the Bureau of Competion's Anticompetitive Practices division, which focuses on shaping Commission-wide policy[25] as well as enforcement efforts. Of course, big tech isn't just looking to poach former antitrust officials as part of its strategy to avoid federal attention — Facebook's recent hire of Sen. Richard Blumenthal's (D-CT) formal counsel on the Senate Judiciary Committee illustrates their appetite for congressional staffers as well. In May, Facebook poached Aparna Patrie as the company's new manager of public policy for its News Tab feature, which has attracted considerable attention given its role in shaping the information users see. In March, Apple hired former DOJ Antitrust senior counsel for intellectual property Frances Marshall as a senior standards counsel. Apple is also currently on the hunt for a new in-house competition counsel, noting in the job listing[26] that 'preference will be given to candidates with government antitrust experience.' Google, meanwhile, has antitrust revolvers like their senior competition counsel (and former DOJ Antitrust attorney) Kevin Yingling to help shepherd the tech giant through the various investigations relatively unharmed. But the revolving door might work in Google's favor more pervasively: The DOJ reportedly hired 'name brand[27]' outside counsel to spearhead potential litigation against the company, seemingly owing to conflicts of interest in the Antitrust Division's leadership. Assistant Attorney General Makan Delrahim recused himself[28] from the investigation, as he lobbied the DOJ in favor of Google's 2007 acquisition of DoubleClick while at Brownstein Hyatt Farber Schreck. Delrahim's deputy, Barry Nigro, also recused[29] himself from the case for unknown reasons; it could be related to his many years at BigLaw practices like Fried Frank. The recusal of the Antitrust Division's top two enforcers makes clear just how entrenched Google is at the highest levels of the antitrust world. Right now, there is a dizzying absence of trustworthy and sustained government experience on the case. As it stands, the case is led by Attorney General Bill Barr, a seemingly corrupt consigliere[30] to President Trump worthy of impeachment[31]; an outside counsel (likely from a BigLaw firm) yet to be named; and two officials who both joined the Division less than nine[32] months[33] ago. Of course, those officials, Ryan Shores and Alex Okuliar, have plenty of experience from the other side of the aisle: Before joining the Division, Shores was a partner in Shearman & Sterling's antitrust practice, while Okuliar came from an antitrust partnership at Orrick, Herrington & Sutcliffe. While their experience might qualify Okuliar and Shores to lead the case in the eyes of the Antitrust Division, their extensive corporate advocacy may hint at another BigLaw gig in the future — and further undermines the ambitions of career DOJ lawyers who hope to ascend to top posts with public service experience alone. While supporters herald the Antitrust Division's case against Google as a long-in-the-works reckoning, the case is distressingly in the hands of officials with conflicts of interest. And that is the power of the revolving door: even when those with explicit conflicts of interest have left the room, those who are left still have questionable dedication to the public interest. The hearing and investigations are an important step in confronting Amazon, Apple, Facebook, and Google, but nonetheless, these companies will continue to use the former government officials who get jobs defending private interests to protect and bolster their monopoly power. To truly challenge the power of big tech, Congress, a potential-future Biden administration and the antitrust enforcement agencies must dismantle the revolving door culture at the agencies and restrict the influence of 'career' antitrust officials who choose to leave public service for corporate clients. Andrea Beaty is a research assistant at the Revolving Door Project[34]. urn:contentItem:5TRV-1X51-DYTY-C4GJ-00000-00TODAY'S EDITION2018-11-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:37:29ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 2TODAY'S EDITION

Grace period in car parks

Motorists will be given a compulsory grace period of five minutes before being ticketed in private car parks under new regulations designed to tackle rogue operators. Page 4

'Duty' to testify against MP

A former aide to a Labour MP who has been accused of lying to police about a speeding offence said that he felt morally obliged to give evidence against her. Page 5

Councils deny help to children

Councils have spent about £100 million over four years to fight parents who seek support for their disabled children, yet the authorities lost nine in ten cases. Page 12

Men 'sacked in diversity drive'

Straight white men felt they had a "target on their backs", a lawyer representing five advertising bosses said after they were forced out of their jobs amid a diversity drive. Page 13

Hint of German national service

Annegret Kramp-Karrenbauer, 56, the favourite to replace Angela Merkel as head of Germany's most powerful party, has hinted at bringing back national service. Page 42

Tech giants face backlash

Bad actions by big tech companies are harming the digital advertising industry, the boss of its largest trade body said, as anger grew over Facebook's campaign to smear rivals. Page 49

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5YBS-NC01-DY7M-10PD-00000-00Today's Events In Washington2020-03-04T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:37:30ZLexisNexisWASHINGTON'S SCHEDULEToday's Events In Washington

White House: -- President Trump - Delivers remarks at the Latino Coalition Legislative Summit; participates in the presentation of the Boy Scouts' Report to the Nation. -- Vice President Pence - Participates in a Coronavirus briefing with Long Term, Post-Acute and Palliative Care Provider CEOs; participates in a Coronavirus briefing with Airline CEOs; participates in a Coronavirus briefing with Diagnostic Lab CEOs; delivers remarks to House GOP Conference; delivers remarks to House Democratic Caucus; leads a meeting with the White House Coronavirus Task Force. US Senate: -- Senate Armed Services subcommittee hearing on U.S. Navy shipbuilding programs - Seapower Subcommittee hearing on 'Navy Shipbuilding Programs', with testimony from Assistant Secretary of the Navy for Research, Development, and Acquisition James Geurts; U.S. Marine Corps Deputy Commandant for Combat Development and Integration and Marine Corps Combat Development Command Commanding General Lt. Gen. Eric Smith; and Deputy Chief of Naval Operations for Warfighting Requirements and Capabilities Vice Adm. James Kilby

Location: Rm 222, Russell Senate Office Building, Washington, DC; 10:00 AM -- House / Senate Veterans' Affairs Committees hear legislative presentation from vets group - House Committee on Veterans Affairs and Senate Committee on Veterans Affairs joint hearing on 'Legislative Presentation of the Veterans of Foreign Wars', with testimony from Veterans of Foreign Wars of the U.S. Commander-in-Chief Doc Schmitz, Executive Director BJ Lawrence, National Veterans Service Director Ryan Gallucci, National Legislative Service Director Carlos Fuentes, and National Legislative Committee Chairman Rusko Rusakiewicz

Location: Rm G50, Dirksen Senate Office Bldg, Washington, DC; 10:00 AM -- Senate Judiciary Committee nominations hearing - Nominations hearing considers John Peter Cronan to be U.S. District Judge for the Southern District of New York; Thomas Cullen to be U.S. District Judge for the Western District of Virginia; and Jennifer Togliatti to be U.S. District Judge for the District of Nevada

Location: Rm 226, Dirksen Senate Office Building, Washington, DC; 10:00 AM -- Senate Public Works Committee hearing on NRC oversight - Hearing on 'Oversight of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission', with testimony from NRC Chairman Kristine Svinicki, and Commissioners Jeff Baran, Annie Caputo, and David Wright

Location: Rm 406, Dirksen Senate Office Building, Washington, DC; 10:00 AM -- Senate Commerce Committee hearing on 5G supply chain security - Hearing on '5G Supply Chain Security: Threats and Solutions', with testimony from Competitive Carriers Association President and CEO Steven Berry; Ericsson North America Network Product Solutions Head of Security Jason Boswell; Intel Corporation Corporate Vice President and General Manager of Next Generation and Standards Asha Keddy; Nokia Americas CTO Mike Murphy; and Center for Strategic and International Studies Technology Policy Program Director Dr James Lewis

Location: Rm 253, Russell Senate Office Building, Washington, DC; 10:00 AM -- Senate Appropriations subcommittee hearing on National Guard and Reserve budgets - Defense Subcommittee hearing on 'Review of the FY2021 Budget Request for the National Guard & Reserve', with testimony from National Guard Bureau Chief Gen. Joseph Lengyel; Army Reserve Chief Lt. Gen. Charles Luckey; Air Force Reserve Chief Lt. Gen. Richard Scobee; Navy Reserve Chief Vice Adm. Luke McCollum; and Marine Corps Forces Reserve Commander Lt. Gen. David Bellon

Location: Rm 138, Dirksen Senate Office Building, Washington, DC; 10:00 AM -- Transportation Secretary Chao testifies to Senate Appropriations subcommittee on FY'21 budget - Transportation, Housing and Urban Development, and Related Agencies Subcommittee hearing on 'Review of the FY2021 Budget Request for the U.S. Department of Transportation', with testimony from Secretary of Transportation Elaine Chao

Location: Rm 192, Dirksen Senate Office Bldg, Washington, DC; 10:00 AM -- Interior Secretary Bernhardt testifies to Senate Appropriations subcommittee hearing on budget - Interior, Environment, and Related Agencies Subcommittee hearing on 'Review of the FY2021 Budget Request for the U.S. Department of the Interior', with testimony from Secretary of the Interior David Bernhardt

Location: Rm 124, Dirksen Senate Office Building, Washington, DC; 10:00 AM -- Senate Armed Services subcommittee part-closed hearing on DoD vetting policies for international military students - Emerging Threats and Capabilities Subcommittee open/closed hearing on 'Department of Defense Review of Vetting Policies for International Military Students Following the Attack on Naval Air Station Pensacola', with testimony from Office of the Under Secretary of Defense for Intelligence and Security Director for Defense Intelligence (Counterintelligence, Law Enforcement, and Security) Garry Reid; and Defense Security Cooperation Agency Director Lt. Gen. Charles Hooper

Location: Rm 232A, Russell Senate Office Building, Washington, DC; 10:00 AM -- Senate Natural Resources subcommittee hearing on invasive species - Water and Power Subcommittee hearing on the impact of invasive species on Bureau of Reclamation facilities and management of water resources in the West, with testimony from Principal Deputy Assistant Secretary of the Interior for Policy Management and Budget Scott Cameron; Buckeye, AZ, Mayor Jackie Meck; Montana Department of Natural Resources Invasive Species Program Manager Stephanie Criswell; Dolores Water Conservancy District Manager of External Relations Mike Preston; and Tahoe Regional Planning Agency Chief of External Affairs and Deputy Director Julie Regan

Location: Rm 366, Dirksen Senate Office Bldg, Washington, DC; 10:30 AM -- Senate Natural Resources subcommittee legislative hearing - National Parks Subcommittee legislative hearing, with testimony from Department of the Interior Acting Deputy Director of Operations Shawn Benge

Location: Rm 366, Dirksen Senate Office Bldg, Washington, DC; 2:00 PM -- Closed Briefing: Intelligence Matters

Location: Rm 219, Hart Senate Office Building, Washington, DC; 2:00 PM -- Senate Judiciary subcommittee hearing on 'Dangerous Partners: Big Tech and Beijing' - Crime and Terrorism Subcommittee hearing on 'Dangerous Partners: Big Tech and Beijing', with testimony from FBI Cyber Operations Branch Deputy Assistant Director Clyde Wallace; Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency Assistant Director for Cybersecurity Bryan Ware; Deputy Assistant Attorney General for the National Security Division Adam Hickey; Stanford Internet Observatory Director Alex Stamos; New America Cybersecurity Policy and China Digital Economy Fellow Samm Sacks; and American Enterprise Institute Resident Scholar Dr Derek Scissors

Location: Rm 226, Dirksen Senate Office Building, Washington, DC; 2:30 PM -- Acting DHS Secretary Wolf testifies to Senate Committee on 'protecting and securing the homeland' - Hearing on 'Resources and Authorities Needed to Protect and Secure the Homeland', with testimony from Acting Secretary of Homeland Security Chad Wolf

Location: Rm 342, Dirksen Senate Office Building, Washington, DC; 2:30 PM -- Senate Indian Affairs Committee legislative hearing - Legislative hearing on 'S. 2610, the Tribal Energy Reauthorization Act of 2019' and 'S. 2891, the Tribal Wildlife Corridors Act of 2019', with testimony from Department of Energy Office of Indian Energy Policy and Programs Director Kevin Frost; U.S. Fish & Wildlife Service Deputy Director for Program Management and Policy Stephen Guertin; Pueblo of Santa Ana Governor Lawrence Montoya; and White Earth Nation Councilman Raymond Auginaush Sr.

Location: Rm 628, Dirksen Senate Office Building, Washington, DC; 2:30 PM -- Energy Secretary Brouillette testifies to Senate Appropriations subcommittee on FY'21 budget - Energy and Water Development Subcommittee hearing on 'Review of the FY2021 Budget Request for the U.S. Department of Energy', with testimony from Secretary of Energy Dan Brouillette

Location: Rm 138, Dirksen Senate Office Building, Washington, DC; 2:30 PM -- Senate Transportation subcommittee hearing on global aviation and infectious disease - Aviation and Space Subcommittee hearing on 'From SARS to Coronavirus: Examining the Role of Global Aviation in Containing the Spread of Infectious Disease', with testimony from Acting Under Secretary of Transportation for Policy Joel Szabat; CDC National Center for Immunization and Respiratory Diseases Director Dr Nancy Messonnier; and Customs and Border Protection Acting Commissioner Mark Morgan

Location: Rm 253, Russell Senate Office Building, Washington, DC; 2:30 PM -- Defense Secretary Esper testifies to Senate Armed Services Committee on budget posture - Hearing on 'Department of Defense Budget Posture', with testimony from Secretary of Defense Mark Esper; and Joint Chiefs of Staff Chairman Gen. Mark Milley

Location: Rm 216, Hart Senate Office Building, Washington, DC; 2:30 PM -- Maryland Congressional delegation members and HBCU leaders meet - Maryland Congressional delegation members Democrats Sens. Ben Cardin and Chris Van Hollen and House Majority Leader Steny Hoyer and fellow Reps. Dutch Ruppersberger, John Sarbanes, Anthony Brown, and David Trone host meeting with leaders of all four of the state's Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs) - Morgan State University President Dr David Wilson, Bowie State University President Dr Aminta Breaux, University of Maryland Eastern Shore President Dr Heidi Anderson, and incoming Coppin State University President Dr Anthony Jenkins - to discuss 'how the federal govt can better support the nation's HBCUs and their students'

Location: S. 207, U.S. Capitol, Washington, DC; 3:30 PM US House: -- EPA Administrator Wheeler testifies to House Appropriations subcommittee on budget - Interior, Environment, and Related Agencies Subcommittee hearing on 'U.S. Environmental Protection Agency Budget Request for FY2021', with testimony from EPA Administrator Andrew Wheeler

Location: Rm 2359, Rayburn House Office Building, Washington, DC; 9:30 AM -- House Appropriations subcommittee hearing on NIH budget - Labor, Health and Human Services, Education, and Related Agencies Subcommittee hearing on 'National Institutes of Health Budget Request for FY 2021', with testimony from National Institutes of Health Director Dr Francis Collins, Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development Director Dr Diana Bianchi, National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases Director Dr Anthony Fauci, National Heart Lung and Blood Institute Director Dr Gary Gibbons, National Cancer Institute Deputy Director Dr Ned Sharpless, and National Institute on Drug Abuse Director Dr Nora Volkow

Location: Rm 2358-C, Rayburn House Office Bldg, Washington, DC; 10:00 AM -- Treasury Secretary Mnuchin testifies to House Appropriations subcommittee on budget - Financial Services and General Government Subcommittee hearing on 'Department of the Treasury Budget Request for FY2021', with testimony from Secretary of the Treasury Steven Mnuchin

urn:contentItem:5XH3-WX41-DY7M-11B6-00000-00Today's Events In Washington2019-11-14T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:37:29ZLexisNexisWASHINGTON'S SCHEDULEToday's Events In Washington

White House: -- President Trump - participates in a working visit with the Secretary General of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization; delivers remarks at a Keep America Great Rally. -- Vice President Pence - tours NASA's Ames Research Center; delivers remarks to NASA's Ames Research Center employees and guests. US Senate: -- Bicameral Dems speaks at Congressional briefing on school diversity - 'Separate and Unequal: How School Diversity Matters for Educational Opportunity and Attainment' Congressional briefing hosted by the Learning Policy Institute, National Coalition on School Diversity, Stanford Graduate School of Education, and Center for Education Policy Analysis, with speakers including Democrats Sen. Chris Murphy and Rep. Marcia Fudge, University of California-Berkeley Professor of Public Policy Rucker Johnson, Stanford University Professor of Poverty and Inequality in Education Sean Reardon, and LPI President Linda Darling-Hammond

Location: Kennedy Caucus Rm, Russell Senate Office Building, Washington, DC; 9:00 AM -- Nominations hearing considers Peter Gaynor to be Federal Emergency Management Agency Administrator

Location: Rm 342, Dirksen Senate Office Building, Washington, DC; 9:30 AM -- U.S.-China Economic and Security Review Commission holds public release of its 2019 Annual Report to Congress

Location: Rm 215, Dirksen Senate Office Building, Washington, DC; 10:00 AM -- Senate Small Business Committee and Entrepreneurship hearing on noncompete agreements and U.S. workers - Hearing on 'Noncompete Agreements and American Workers', with testimony from Keith Bollinger of Conover, NC; University of Maryland Robert H. Smith School of Business Assistant Professor of Management and Organization Dr Evan Starr; and Economic Innovation Group President and CEO John Lettieri

Location: Rm 428A, Russell Senate Office Building, Washington, DC; 10:00 AM -- Senate Judiciary Committee Executive Business Meeting - Executive Business Meeting, with agenda including nominations of Patrick Bumatay and Lawrence VanDyke to be U.S. Circuit Judge for the Ninth Circuit; Philip Halpern to be U.S. District Judge for the Southern District of New York; Bernard Maurice Jones II to be U.S. District Judge for the Western District of Oklahoma; and Barbara Bailey Jongbloed to be U.S. District Judge for the District of Connecticut

Location: Rm 226, Dirksen Senate Office Building, Washington, DC; 10:00 AM -- Senate Administration Committee annual oversight hearing on the Smithsonian - Annual oversight hearing on 'The Smithsonian Institution', with testimony from Smithsonian Institution Secretary Lonnie Bunch III

Location: Rm 301, Russell Senate Office Building, Washington, DC; 10:00 AM -- Senate committee hearing considers energy secretary nominee - Nominations hearing considers Dan Brouillette to be Secretary of Energy * President Donald Trump announced the nomination of the current deputy secretary of energy last month, to replace Rick Perry, who is resigning later this year

Location: Rm 366, Dirksen Senate Office Bldg, Washington, DC; 10:30 AM -- Bicameral Dems discuss Trump administration's Title X gag rule at 'Protect Our Birth Control' press conference - Democrats Sens. Sherrod Brown, Patty Murray, and Mazie Hirono and Reps. Judy Chu, Rosa DeLauro, and Barbara Lee hold 'Protect Our Birth Control' press conference to discuss the importance of protecting access to birth control and blocking the Trump administration's harmful Title X gag rule in the year-end spending bills. Other speakers include Physicians for Reproductive Health Dr Serina Floyd and Drt Sapna Dalsy

Location: S-120, United States Capitol, East Capitol St NE & First St SE, Washington, DC; 11:00 AM -- Nominations hearing considers Hugh Nathanial Halpern to be Government Publishing Office Director

Location: U.S. Capitol, Washington, DC; 11:00 AM -- Closed Briefing: Intelligence Matters

Location: Rm 219, Hart Senate Office Building, Washington, DC; 2:00 PM US House: -- House Commerce subcommittee markup hearing - Consumer Protection and Commerce Subcommittee markup hearing on 'H.R. 3851, the Travel Promotion, Enhancement and Modernization Act of 2019' and 'H.R. 4779, a bill to extend the Undertaking Spam, Spyware, And Fraud Enforcement With Enforcers beyond Borders (US SAFEWEB) Act of 2006, and for other purposes'

Location: Rm 2123, Rayburn House Office Building, Washington, DC; 9:30 AM -- House Veterans Affairs subcommittee oversight hearing on VA cybersecurity challenges - Technology Modernization Subcommittee oversight hearing on 'Cybersecurity Challenges and Cyber Risk Management at the Department of Veterans Affairs', with testimony from Deputy Assistant Secretary of Veterans Affairs and VA Chief Information Security Officer Paul Cunningham; VA Executive Director for Information Security Policy and Strategy and Deputy Chief Information Security Officer Gary Stevens, Deputy CIO for Strategic Sourcing Luwanda Jones, Deputy Assistant Inspector General for Audits and Evaluations Nick Dahl, and Office of the Inspector General Information Technology and Security Audits Division Director Michael Bowman; Veterans Health Administration Procurement and Logistics Office Executive Director of Procurement and Logistics Andrew Centineo; and Government Accountability Office Director of Information Technology and Cybersecurity Greg Wilshusen

Location: HVC-210, U.S. Capitol Visitor Center, Washington, DC; 10:00 AM -- House Appropriations subcommittee hearing on 'VA Office of Accountability and Whistleblower Protection failures' - Military Construction, Veterans Affairs, and Related Agencies Subcommittee hearing on 'Office of Accountability and Whistleblower Protection's Failures at VA', with testimony from Assistant Secretary of Veterans Affairs for Accountability and Whistleblower Protection Dr Tamara Bonzanto; and Department of Veterans Affairs Inspector General Michael Missal

Location: Rm 2362-A, Rayburn House Office Building, Washington, DC; 10:00 AM -- House Agriculture subcommittee hearing on safeguarding U.S. agriculture from wild, invasive, and non-native species - Livestock and Foreign Agriculture Subcommittee hearing on 'Safeguarding American Agriculture from Wild, Invasive, and Non-Native Species'

Location: Rm 1300, Longworth House Office Bldg, Washington, DC; 10:00 AM -- Fed Chair Powell testifies to House Budget Committee - Hearing on 'The Economic Outlook: The View from the Federal Reserve', with testimony from Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell - the first appearance by the Federal Reserve chair before the House Committee on the Budget since 2012

Location: Rm 210, Cannon House Office Building, Washington, DC; 10:00 AM -- House Transportation subcommittee hearing on the air travel experience for disabled people - Aviation Subcommittee hearing on 'From Curb to Gate and Back Again: The Air Travel Experience for Persons with Disabilities'

Location: Rm 2167, Rayburn House Office Building, Washington, DC; 10:00 AM -- Hearing on 'Caring for Aging Americans'

Location: Rm 1100, Longworth House Office Building, Washington, DC; 10:00 AM -- House Judiciary subcommittee hearing on reform of court-administered bail - Crime, Terrorism and Homeland Security Subcommittee hearing on 'The Administration of Bail by State and Federal Courts: A Call for Reform', with testimony from American Civil Liberties Union Criminal Law Reform Project Deputy Director for Smart Justice Litigation Brandon Buskey; The Bail Project National Director of Strategic Partnerships Shelton McElroy; University of Chicago Law School Federal Criminal Justice Clinic Director Alison Siegler; Ohio Professional Bail Agents Association President Mary Smith; and The Leadership Conference on Civil and Human Rights Justice Reform Program Director Sakira Cook

Location: Rm 2141, Rayburn House Office Building, Washington, DC; 10:00 AM -- House Natural Resources subcommittee legislative hearing - Energy and Mineral Resources Subcommittee legislative hearing on 'H.R. 4248, Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act Amendments of 2019'

Location: Rm 1324, Longworth House Office Building, Washington, DC; 10:00 AM -- U.S.-China Economic and Security Review Commission holds public release of its 2019 Annual Report to Congress

Location: Rm 215, Dirksen Senate Office Building, Washington, DC; 10:00 AM -- House Small Business subcommittee first hearing on govt role in serving rural small businesses - Rural Development, Agriculture, Trade, and Entrepreneurship Subcommittee hearing on 'Assessing the Government's Role in Serving Rural American Small Businesses (Part One)', with testimony from Small Business Administration Office of Rural Affairs National Director Michelle Christian; and USDA-Rural Development Rural Business-Cooperative Service Administrator Bette Brand

Location: Rm 2360, Rayburn House Office Building, Washington, DC; 10:00 AM -- House Science, Space, and Technology Committee markup hearing - Markup hearing on 'H.R. 4979, the Rural STEM Education Act', 'H.R. 4704, the Advancing Research to Prevent Suicide Act', and 'H.R. 4990, the Election Technology Research Act'

Location: Rm 2318, Rayburn House Office Bldg, Washington, DC; 10:00 AM -- Bicameral Dems discuss Trump administration's Title X gag rule at 'Protect Our Birth Control' press conference - Democrats Sens. Sherrod Brown, Patty Murray, and Mazie Hirono and Reps. Judy Chu, Rosa DeLauro, and Barbara Lee hold 'Protect Our Birth Control' press conference to discuss the importance of protecting access to birth control and blocking the Trump administration's harmful Title X gag rule in the year-end spending bills. Other speakers include Physicians for Reproductive Health Dr Serina Floyd and Drt Sapna Dalsy

Location: S-120, United States Capitol, East Capitol St NE & First St SE, Washington, DC; 11:00 AM -- House meets for legislative business - House of Representatives meets for legislative business, with agenda for the week including 'H.R. 4863 - United States Export Finance Agency Act of 2019' and consideration of H.R. 4803 - Citizenship for Children of Military Members and Civil Servants Act', 'H.R. 4258 - Reauthorizing Security for Supreme Court Justices Act of 2019', 'H.R. 1663 - Foundation of the Federal Bar Association Charter Amendments Act of 2019', 'H.R. 3537 - Veteran Entrepreneur Training Act of 2019', 'H.R. 3661 - Patriotic Employer Protection Act of 2019', as amended, 'H.R. 499 - Service-Disabled Veterans Small Business Continuation Act', 'H.R. 3734 - SERV Act', as amended, 'H.R. 1615 - VA-SBA Act', as amended, and 'H.R. 1773 - Rosie the Riveter Congressional Gold Medal Act of 2019' under suspension of the rules

Location: U.S. Capitol, Washington, DC; 12:00 PM -- Amazon and Google executives testify to House Small Business Committee hearing on impact of big tech - Hearing on 'A Fair Playing Field? Investigating Big Tech's Impact on Small Business', with testimony from Amazon Vice President for Customer Trust and Partner Support Dharmesh Mehta; Google Head of Community Engagement for Grow with Google Erica Swanson; Information Technology & Innovation Foundation Senior Fellow Joe Kennedy; Meadowmere Resort Principal and owner Allyson Cavaretta; Viahart Toy Company CEO Molson Hart; Public Knowledge Senior Vice President Harold Feld; Spa Destinations co-founder and CEO Theo Prodromitis; Connected Commerce Council President Jake Ward; and ACT: The App Association Senior Director for Public Policy Graham Dufault

Location: Rm 2360, Rayburn House Office Building, Washington, DC; 1:00 PM -- Hearing on 'Examining State Efforts to Undermine Access to Reproductive Health Care'

Location: Rm 2154, Rayburn House Office Building, Washington, DC; 2:00 PM -- Dem Rep. Dan Kildee hosts 'Using Data to Improve Children's Prospects in America's Cities and Towns' briefing - Democratic Rep. Dan Kildee hosts briefing on 'Creating Opportunity: Using Data to Improve Children's Prospects in America's Cities and Towns', on the research of Harvard economist Raj Chetty, as part of his 'The Future of America's Cities and Towns' initiative. National Academy of Sciences Executive Editor Stephen Mautner introduces the science behind research to improve outcomes for children, then Opportunity Insights Associate Director of Policy and Research Sarah Oppenheimer discusses 'how data and research can improve policies for cities and towns'

Location: Rm 303, Cannon House Office Building, Washington, DC; 2:00 PM -- House Natural Resources subcommittee oversight hearing on NOAA report on illegal, unreported, and unregulated fishing - Water, Oceans, and Wildlife Subcommittee oversight hearing on 'Oversight of NOAA's Report on Illegal, Unreported, and Unregulated Fishing'

Location: Rm 1324, Longworth House Office Building, Washington, DC; 2:00 PM -- House Foreign Affairs subcommittee hearing on U.S. policy in the Sahel region - Africa, Global Health, Global Human Rights and International Organizations Subcommittee hearing on 'The U.S. Policy in the Sahel Region', with testimony from Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for West Africa and Security Affairs Whitney Baird; and USAID Acting Senior Deputy Assistant Administrator for Policy, Planning and Learning Cheryl Anderson

Location: Rm 2172, Rayburn House Office Building, Washington, DC; 2:00 PM -- House Judiciary subcommittee hearing on 'the use of 'snap' removals to circumvent the forum defendant rule' - Courts, Intellectual Property, and the Internet Subcommittee hearing on 'Examining the Use of 'Snap' Removals to Circumvent the Forum Defendant Rule', with testimony from University of Pittsburgh School of Law Professor of Law Emeritus Arthur Hellman; Northwestern University Pritzker School of Law Professor James Pfander; Weitz & Luxenberg Of Counsel Ellen Relkin; and Bartlit Beck partner Kaspar Stoffelmayr

Location: Rm 2141, Rayburn House Office Building, Washington, DC; 2:00 PM -- House Technology subcommittee hearing on water and geothermal power - Energy Subcommittee hearing on 'Water and Geothermal Power: Unearthing the Next Wave of Energy Innovation', with testimony from Deputy Assistant Secretary of Energy for Renewable Power Dr David Solan; Oregon State University Associate Professor of Civil and Construction Engineering Dr Bryson Robertson; University of Utah Research Professor Dr Joseph Moore; Southern Methodist University Roy M. Huffington Department of Earth Sciences Geothermal Laboratory Director Maria Richards; and Enel Green Power North America Director of Innovation Sander Cohan

Location: Rm 2318, Rayburn House Office Building, Washington, DC; 2:00 PM -- House Transportation subcommittee hearing on vessel safety - Coast Guard and Maritime Transportation Subcommittee hearing on 'Commercial and Passenger Vessel Safety: Challenges and Opportunities'

Location: Rm 2167, Rayburn House Office Building, Washington, DC; 2:00 PM -- Tom Lantos Human Rights Commission hearing on Jammu and Kashmir - Tom Lantos Human Rights Commission hearing on 'Jammu and Kashmir in Context', examining the human rights situation in the former state of Jammu and Kashmir in India in historical and national context, and offering recommendations for action by Congress. Witnesses are U.S. Commission on International Religious Freedom Commissioner Anurima Bhargava, Ohio University Associate Professor of Anthropology Haley Duschinski, human rights lawyers Sehla Ashai, Yousra Fazili, and Arjun Sethi, and Human Rights Watch Asia Advocacy Director John Sifton

Location: Rm 2200, Rayburn House Office Building, Washington, DC; 2:00 PM -- House Ethics Committee self-imposed deadline to announce update on GOP Rep. Ross Spano - House Committee on Ethics due to announce its course of action on the matter regarding Republican Rep. Ross Spano - which was referred to the Committee by the Office of Congressional Ethics in August - on or before today * Matter was extended in September, although with the Committee noting that the extension 'does not itself indicate that any violation has occurred, or reflect any judgment on behalf of the Committee' * Reasons for investigations are generally kept secret, although Rep. Spano has admitted to breaching campaign finance laws by borrowing around $180,000 from friends and contributing it to his Congressional campaign as his own money -- House Ethics Committee self-imposed deadline to announce update on Dem Rep. Rashida Tlaib - House Committee on Ethics due to announce its course of action on the matter regarding Democratic Rep. Rashida Tlaib - which was referred to the Committee by the Office of Congressional Ethics in August - on or before today * Matter was extended in September, although with the Committee noting that the extension 'does not itself indicate that any violation has occurred, or reflect any judgment on behalf of the Committee' * Reasons for investigations are generally kept secret, although Rep. Tlaib has faced claims - which her office denies - that she reimbursed herself after her 2018 election using campaign funds -- House Ethics Committee self-imposed deadline to announce update on GOP Rep. Bill Huizenga - House Committee on Ethics due to announce its course of action on the matter regarding Republican Rep. Bill Huizenga - which was referred to the Committee by the Office of Congressional Ethics in August - on or before today * Matter was extended in September, although with the Committee noting that the extension 'does not itself indicate that any violation has occurred, or reflect any judgment on behalf of the Committee' * Reasons for investigations are generally kept secret, although Rep. Huizenga has faced claims that he and his family misused thousands of dollars of campaign funds - accusations he has denied Cabinet Officers: -- Global Coalition to Defeat ISIS foreign ministers meeting - Secretary of State Mike Pompeo hosts extraordinary meeting with the foreign ministers of the Global Coalition to Defeat ISIS Small Group (which features around 35 member states and organizations), to review next steps in 'the joint campaign to achieve the enduring defeat of the Islamic State group', with agenda including remarks from Secretary Pompeo (10:00 AM EST) and working luncheon (12:15 PM EST, closed press) * Earlier, Secretary Pompeo also meets Syria Small Group (Jordan, Saudi Arabia, Egypt, France, the UK, France, Germany, and the U.S.) Ministerial participants (9:00 AM EST)

Location: Washington, DC -- Secretary of State Mike Pompeo meets NATO Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg at the State Department

Location: State Department, Washington, DC -- International Framework for Nuclear Energy Cooperation Global Ministerial Conference concludes - International Framework for Nuclear Energy Cooperation (IFNEC) Global Ministerial Conference, 'Bringing the World SMRs and Advanced Nuclear'. Day two includes remarks from outgoing Secretary of Energy Rick Perry

Location: Washington, DC Visitors: -- Under Secretary of State Hale meets South Korea Ambassador to the U.S. - Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs David Hale agenda includes meeting South Korea Ambassador to the U.S. Amb. Lee Soo-hyuck

Location: State Department, Washington, DC -- Afghan first lady speaks at USIP - Afghan First Lady Rula Ghani speaks at the U.S. Institute of Peace on 'How to Protect Afghan Women's Rights and Build Consensus for Peace', discussing her role in the Afghan Women's National Consensus for Peace (Ejma-e-Mili), as well as other current events on peace, security, and governance in Afghanistan

Location: United States Institute of Peace, 2301 Constitution Ave NW, Washington, DC; 10:00 AM This Town: -- Axios discussion with Dem Sen. Kirsten Gillibrand and GOP Rep. Mac Thornberry - Axios 360: New Shapers event, with Axios" Mike Allen hosting one-on-one conversations on news of the day with Democratic Sen. Kirsten Gillibrand, Republican Rep. Mac Thornberry and former White House Chief of Staff Denis McDonough

Location: The Showroom, 1099 14th St NW, Washington, DC; 8:00 AM -- Cato Institute Annual Monetary Conference - Cato Institute Annual Monetary Conference, 'Fed Policy: A Shadow Review'. Speakers include Federal Reserve Board Vice Chairman Richard Clarida and former Bank of England Deputy Governor Sir Paul Tucker

Location: Cato Institute, 1000 Massachusetts Ave NW, Washington, DC; 8:30 AM -- U.S. Postal Service Board of Governors meets - U.S. Postal Service Board of Governors meeting, with agenda including remarks from CEO and U.S. Postmaster General Megan Brennan (9:00 AM EST) * After the meeting, CEO Brennan and CFO Joe Corbett host media conference call to discuss the FY2019 financial results (11:30 AM EST)

Location: U.S. Postal Service Headquarters, 475 L'Enfant Plaza SW, Washington, DC; 9:00 AM -- National Action Network Legislative and Policy Conference - National Action Network Legislative and Policy Conference: 'From Demonstration to Legislation', with speakers including Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer and fellow Democrats Sens. Amy Klobuchar, Kirsten Gillibrand, Jeff Merkley, Mark Warner, Mazie Hirono, and Gary Peters and Reps. Al Green, Hakeem Jeffries, Ilhan Omar, Ayanna Pressley, Terri Sewell, Rashida Tlaib, Adrianno Espaillat, and Hank Johnson

Location: Rm 902, Hart Senate Office Building, Washington, DC; 9:00 AM -- Vaccine Injury Epidemic event - Children's health 'advocates' hold a Vaccine Injury Epidemic rally, marking the 33rd anniversary of the National Childhood Vaccine Injury Act (NCVIA). Protesters allege that 'children continue to be injured by vaccines daily' and that vaccine makers have no 'incentive' to ensure their pharmaceuticals are safe. Children's Health Defense Chairman Robert F. Kennedy Jr. addresses the rally

Location: National Mall, Washington, DC; 10:00 AM -- ICE releases HSI child exploitation year-end results at grand opening of Angel Watch center - Immigrations and Customs Enforcement (ICE) holds a grand opening ceremony for the Angel Watch Center - a 'state-of-the-art' facility to combat child sex tourism - with agenda including release of the fiscal year 2019 Homeland Security Investigations child exploitation results. Speakers include ICE Acting Director Matthew Albence and U.S. Marshals Service Deputy Assistant Director Richard Kelly; 10:00 AM -- Washington, DC, Economic Partnership 2019 Annual Meeting and ECON Showcase - Washington, DC, Economic Partnership 2019 Annual Meeting and ECON Showcase, with speakers including Washington, DC Mayor Muriel Bowser, Interim Deputy Mayor for Planning and Economic Development John Falcicchio, Councilmembers Kenyan McDuffie and Jack Evans, Children's National President and CEO Dr Kurt Newman, and Washington Business Journal Editor-in-Chief Vandana Sinha

Location: Walter E. Washington Convention Center, 801 Mount Vernon Pl NW, Washington, DC; 10:00 AM -- Diplomatic Security Service opens new Foreign Affairs Security Training Center - Diplomatic Security Service Foreign Affairs Security Training Center inaugural ceremony, formally opening the doors of the facility which features three high-speed driving tracks, off-road and improved tracks, explosives ranges, tactical structures, and two smokehouses. State Department officials deliver remarks, and journalists can hold pull-aside interviews and tour the facility

Location: Foreign Affairs Security Training Center, Blackstone, VA; 10:30 AM -- Democratic Rep. Bennie Thompson speaks at Georgetown University's 2019 'State of Cyber' conference

Location: Georgetown University, 640 Massachusetts Ave NW, Washington, DC; 10:30 AM -- Department of Transportation September Air Travel Consumer Report released - Department of Transportation September Air Travel Consumer Report released, containing September airline on-time numbers, tarmac times, mishandled baggage numbers, mishandled wheelchair and scooter numbers, and consumer complaints for reporting marketing and operating carriers; 11:00 AM -- House Dems speak at CAP on how to build a 100% clean energy future - 'How To Build a 100 Percent Clean Future' Center for American Progress discussion, co-hosted with the Environmental Defense Fund, League of Conservation Voters, and Sierra Club, with Democratic Reps. Debbie Dingell, Joe Neguse, and Paul Tonko discussing 'pathways the federal govt can take to build a 100% clean energy future'. Other speakers include Nevada Conservation League Operations Director Barb Hartzell, EDF Regulatory Strategy Senior Director Pam Kiely, and National Audubon Society State Campaigns Manger Adam Maxwell

Location: Center For American Progress, 1333 H St NW, Washington, DC; 12:30 PM -- Graduate workers protest Trump administration's anti-union rule - Graduate workers with the American Federation of Teachers hold a rally to protest the Trump administration's proposed rule that would 'strip grads' right to unionize' despite federal law stating that graduate employees at private schools and colleges are workers entitled to the same protections as others * Protests also held in Chicago and Boston

Location: National Labor Relations Board, 1015 Half St SE, Washington, DC; 1:00 PM -- Department of Education National Assessment Governing Board quarterly meeting

Location: The Westin Arlington Gateway, 801 N Glebe Rd, Arlington, VA; 4:00 PM -- Dem Rep. Donna Shalala attends CLASP 50th anniversary celebration - CLASP holds event to mark 50th anniversary, with guests including Democratic Rep. Donna Shalala, National Domestic Workers Alliance Directior Ai-Jen Poo, Annie E. Casey Foundation President and CEO Lisa Hamilton, CLASP Board of Trustees Chair LaVeeda Battle, and CLASP Executive Director Olivia Golden

Location: District Winery, Ana at District Winery, 385 Water St SE, Washington, DC; 5:30 PM -- 7th Annual New American Hero Awards, with House Dems attending - New American Leaders holds seventh annual New American Hero Awards reception, recognizing leaders from immigrant communities and communities of color. Honorees include Democratic Rep. Veronica Escobar, Virginia State Rep. Kathy Tran, and New York State Rep. Catalina Cruz, with event also featuring remarks from Democratic Rep. Rashida Tlaib, New Virginia Majority Co-Executive Director Tram Nguyen, and New American Leaders founder and President Sayu Bhojwani

Location: Long View Gallery, 1234 9th St NW, Washington, DC; 6:30 PM -- DoD holds community meeting in Alexandria, VA, over plans to move mail screening off Pentagon Reservation - Department of Defense officials hold community meeting - at the request of the City of Alexandria, VA - to provide information and answer questions about the Department's plans to screen incoming mail and other deliveries at the DoD Mark Center Building in Alexandria * The current Pentagon mail screening facility, which was built following the 9/11 attacks, was intended for temporary use until a permanent facility could be built, with the Department now saying that it 'has reached the end of its useful service life and must be replaced', while the Mark Center Building - which houses DoD offices - was built with a mail screening facility that is not currently in use, and the Pentagon Force Protection Agency plans to move its mail screening operation their once the new facility is ready early next year

Location: Francis C. Hammond Middle School, Alexandria, VA; 7:00 PM -- Nikki Haley continues 'With All Due Respect' book tour in Washington, DC - Former U.S. Ambassador to the United Nations and former South Carolina Governor Nikki Haley continues 'With All Due Respect: Defending America with Grit and Grace' book tour in Washington, DC

Location: Lisner Auditorium, George Washington University, 730 21st St NW, Washington, DC; 7:00 PM -- U.S. Chamber of Commerce Foundation Corporate Citizenship Awards - U.S. Chamber of Commerce Foundation Corporate Citizenship Center Corporate Citizenship Awards (aka Citizens Awards) Annual Gala, which honor companies that are 'tackling some of society's toughest issues, including childhood obesity, disease prevention, environmental sustainability, and community revitalization' * Held during the Corporate Citizenship Conference

Location: U.S. Chamber of Commerce, 1615 H St NW, Washington, DC

urn:contentItem:5XF6-5921-JBSJ-902S-00000-00Today's Events In Washington2019-11-05T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:37:29ZLexisNexisWASHINGTON'S SCHEDULEToday's Events In Washington

White House:

President Trump - has no public events scheduled. -- Vice President Pence - participates in the Senate Republican Policy lunch. US Senate: -- Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee nominations hearing - Nominations hearing considers James Danly to be a Federal Energy Regulatory Commission member; and Katharine MacGregor to be Deputy Secretary of the Interior

Location: Rm 366, Dirksen Senate Office Bldg, Washington, DC; 10:00 AM -- Senate debates judicial nominee - Senate convenes and resumes consideration of the nomination of David Austin Tapp to be a U.S. Court of Federal Claims Judge

Location: U.S. Capitol, Washington, DC; 10:00 AM -- Dem Sen. Ben Cardin speaks on 'lack of accountability' surrounding the private detention industry - Democratic Sen. Ben Cardin leads briefing - hosted by Open the Government, Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington (CREW), and the ACLU - to discuss the 'lack of accountability' surrounding private prisons, jails, and detention centers that house federal inmates. Other speakers include Open the Government Executive Director Lisa Rosenberg, CREW team member Mia Woodard, and ACLU National Prison Project Staff Attorney Eunice Cho

Location: Rm 188, Russell Senate Office Building, 2 Constitution Ave NE, Washington, DC; 11:30 AM -- Senate Homeland Security Committee hearing on 'Threats to the Homeland' - Hearing on 'Threats to the Homeland', with testimony from Acting Secretary of Homeland Security Kevin McAleenan, accompanied by Under Secretary of Homeland Security for Intelligence and Analysis David Glawe; FBI Director Christopher Wray; and National Counterterrorism Center Acting Director Russell Travers * Acting Secretary McAleenan had been due to leave his post last week, but is staying on to assist the transition to Acting Under Secretary of Homeland Security for Strategy, Policy, and Plans Chad Wolf, who is due to take over as acting under secretary of homeland security after Veterans' Day

Location: Rm 216, Hart Senate Office Building, Washington, DC; 2:30 PM -- Senate Commerce Committee hearing on NASA engagement in STEM education - Aviation and Space Subcommittee hearing on 'Building NASA's Workforce of the Future: STEM Engagement for a 21st Century Education', with testimony from University of Mississippi Vice Chancellor of Research Dr Josh Gladden; Nanoracks CEO Jeffrey Manber; and NASA Psyche Mission Principal Investigator Dr Linda Tarbox Elkins-Tanton (Arizona State University)

Location: Rm 562, Dirksen Senate Office Building, Washington, DC; 2:30 PM -- Senate Judiciary subcommittee hearing on 'how corporations and big tech leave our data exposed' - Crime and Terrorism Subcommittee hearing on 'How Corporations and Big Tech Leave Our Data Exposed to Criminals, China, and Other Bad Actors'

Location: Rm 226, Dirksen Senate Office Building, Washington, DC; 2:30 PM US House: -- House meets in pro forma session - House of Representatives meets in pro forma session * Chamber is on recess from 1 Nov - 11 Nov; 8:00 AM -- House Committees due to jointly conduct deposition with OMB official, as part of impeachment inquiry - House Committee on Foreign Affairs, Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence, and Committee on Oversight and Reform due to jointly conduct deposition with Office of Management and Budget Associate Director for National Security Programs Michael Duffey, with the transcript to be part of the impeachment inquiry into President Donald Trump, following the issuance of a subpoena after the administration informed House Democrats that it is refusing to comply with the inquiry, calling it unconstitutional * The Committees are investigating 'the extent to which President Trump jeopardized national security by pressing Ukraine to interfere with the 2020 election and by withholding security assistance provided by Congress to help Ukraine counter Russian aggression, as well as any efforts to cover up these matters'

Location: HVC-304, U.S. Capitol Visitor Center, Washington, DC; 9:30 AM -- House Committees due to jointly conduct deposition with NSC official, as part of impeachment inquiry - House Committee on Foreign Affairs, Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence, and Committee on Oversight and Reform due to jointly conduct deposition with National Security Council International Energy and Environment Director Wells Griffith, with the transcript to be part of the impeachment inquiry into President Donald Trump * The Committees are investigating 'the extent to which President Trump jeopardized national security by pressing Ukraine to interfere with the 2020 election and by withholding security assistance provided by Congress to help Ukraine counter Russian aggression, as well as any efforts to cover up these matters' * The administration has informed House Democrats that it is refusing to comply with the inquiry, calling it unconstitutional

Location: U.S. Capitol, Washington, DC Cabinet Officers: -- No public schedules released. Visitors: -- No visitors scheduled. This Town: -- Federal Emergency Management Agency National Advisory Council meeting

Location: National Association of Counties, 660 North Capitol St NW, Washington, DC; 8:00 AM -- National Security Commission on Artificial Intelligence Conference - National Security Commission on Artificial Intelligence Conference, 'Strength Through Innovation: The Future of Artificial Intelligence and U.S. National Security', with speakers including Secretary of Energy Rick Perry; Secretary of Defense Mark Esper; Senate Minority Leader Chuck Shumer; Republicans Sen. Joni Ernst and Rep. Elise Stefanik; former Secretary of State Henry Kissinger, National Science Foundation Director France Cordova; DARPA Director Steven Walker; Chief Technology Officer of the U.S. Michael Kratsios; Office of the Director of National Intelligence Principal Executive Andrew Hallman; Rasmussen Global CEO Anders Fogh Rasmussen; WestExec co-founder and Managing Partner Michele Flournoy; Under Secretary of State for Arms Control and International Security Andrea Thompson; former Deputy National Security Advisor Nadia Schadlow; former Principal Deputy Director of National Intelligence Susan Gordon; and NSCAI Chair Eric Schmidt and Vice Chairman Robert Work

Location: Liaison Washington Capitol Hill, 415 New Jersey Ave NW, Washington, DC; 8:30 AM -- Jury trial of Roger Stone on charges including obstruction - Jury trial of Roger Stone, an associate of President Donald Trump, on seven charges: one count of obstruction of an official proceeding, five counts of false statements, and one count of witness tampering * Stone, who has pleaded not guilty to the charges, was arrested in Florida on 25 Jan as part of Special Counsel Robert Mueller's investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 presidential election

Location: U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia, 333 Constitution Ave NW, Washington, DC; 9:30 AM -- Dem Sen. Ed Markey discusses U.S.-Japan alliance at CAP - Center for American Progress holds panel discussion to assess how the U.S.-Japan alliance can play a key role in upholding human rights and democracy in Asia. Keynote from Democratic Sen. Ed Markey, with panelists including former U.S. Ambassador to Thailand Kristie Kenney, Alliance for Peacebuilding President and CEO Uzra Zeya, Center on Democracy Visting Scholar Maiko Ichihara, and journalist Abby Seiff

Location: Center For American Progress, 1333 H St NW, Washington, DC; 9:30 AM -- Brookings discussion on fighting democratic backsliding, with Dem Sen. Ben Cardin - Brookings Institution holds event to release 'The Democracy Playbook', a new report examining strategies to halt and reverse democratic backsliding and make democratic institutions work more effectively for citizens, with a particular focus on the European experience. Keynote from Democratic Sen. Ben Cardin, with other speakers including authors Brookings fellows Norman Eisen, Alina Polyakova, and Torey Taussig, and German Marshall Fund Senior Fellow Susan Corke

Location: Brookings Institution, 1775 Massachusetts Ave NW, Washington, DC; 9:30 AM -- NTSB meeting on bicyclist safety research report - National Transportation Safety Board meeting, to adopt the findings and recommendations of Safety Research Report 'Bicyclist safety on US Roadways: Crash Risks and Countermeasures' - its first analysis of bicyclist safety in 47 years, which 'updates the agency's understanding of bicyclist safety in the U.S. by examining the prevalence and risk factors of bicycle crashes involving motor vehicles and assessing the most applicable countermeasures'

Location: NTSB, 420 10th St SW, Washington, DC; 9:30 AM -- U.S. Supreme Court hearings - U.S. Supreme Court hearings: 'CITGO Asphalt Refining Company v. Frescati Shipping Company' (Whether, under federal maritime law, a safe berth clause in a voyage charter contract is a guarantee of a ship's safety, or a duty of due diligence?) * 'Allen v. Cooper' (Whether Congress validly abrogated state sovereign immunity via the Copyright Remedy Clarification Act (1990) in providing remedies for authors of original expression whose federal copyrights are infringed by states?)

Location: Supreme Court of the United States, Washington, DC; 10:00 AM -- CDC telebriefing on new 'Vital Signs' ACE report - CDC telebriefing on new 'Vital Signs' report which finds '14 negative long-term social and health outcomes in adults are associated with Adverse Childhood Experiences (ACEs)' and discusses 'what can be done to reduce negative health outcomes caused by ACEs?', with speakers including CDC Principal Deputy Director Anne Schuchat; 12:00 PM -- ECA English Language Fellow Program 50th anniversary celebration - State Department Bureau of Educational and Cultural Affairs celebrates the 50th anniversary of the English Language Fellow Program, with remarks from Assistant Secretary of State for Educational and Cultural Affairs Marie Royce and Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs. ECA presents awards to three alumni and to seven U.S. universities that have been important partners in the success of the Fellow program: University of Colorado Boulder, University of Oregon, School of International Training, Columbia University, Middlebury Institute of International Studies, University of Washington, and San Francisco State University

Location: State Department, 2201 C St NW, Washington, DC; 5:30 PM -- DCHabitat for Humanity 30th Anniversary Celebration - Habitat for Humanity of Washington DC holds 30th anniversary celebration, with honorees including Republican Sen. Rob Portman, DC Mayor Muriel Bowser, Pentagon Federal Credit Union President and CEO James Schenck, and GEICO

Location: Union Station, 50 Massachusetts Ave NE, Washington, DC; 6:00 PM -- CNN journalists discuss 2020 election at GW - George Washington University holds panel discussion to preview year ahead leading into the 2020 presidential election. Participants include CNN Chief Political Correspondent Dana Bash, former Hillary Clinton campaign advisor Karen Finney, C-SPAN political editor Steve Scully, and former Romney 2012 presidential campaign spokesperson Kevin Madden, with NBC News Political Director and anchor Chuck Todd moderating

Location: George Washington University School of Media and Public Affairs, 805 21st St NW, Washington, DC; 7:00 PM
